div3.head: Proclamation by the President.
div3.p: It is meet that, as a people who acknowledge the supremacy of the living God, we should be ever mindful of our dependence on Him; should remember that to Him alone can we true, for our deliverance; that to Him is one devout thankfulness for the signal merles bestowed on as; and that by prayer alone can we hope to secure the continued manifestation of that protecting care which has hitherto shielded us in the midst of trials and dangers,

In obedience to His precepts we have from time to time been gathered together with prayers and thanksgiving, and He has been graciously pleased to hear our supplications, and to grant abundant exhibitions of His favor to our Armin and our people.
Through many conflictswe have now at, tained a place among the nations which commands their respect; and to the enemies who encompass us around and seek our destruction the Lord of Hocts has again taught the lesson of His inspired word; That the battle is not to the strong, but to whomsoever He villeth to exalt.

Again our enemy, with load boasting of the power of their armed and maited ships threaten us with subjugation, and, with evil machinations, seek, even in our own homes and at our own firesides, to prevent our menservants, and our maidservants into accomplices of their wicked design,

Under these circumstances it is my privilege to invite you ones more to meet together and to prostrate yourselves in humble supplication to him who has been our constant and never falling support in the post, and to whose protection and guidance we trust for the future.

To this end I Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America do issue this my proclamation setting apart Friday, the 27th day of March,as a day of fasting, humiliation, and prayer, and I do invite the people of the safe States to repair on that day to their usual places of public worship, and to join in prayer to Almighty God that he will continue His merciful protection over our cause, but He will setter our enemies, and set at naught their evil design, and that He will graciously restore to our beloved country the hissing of peace and security.
In faith where of I have hereunto set my hand at the city of Richmond on the twenty-seventh day of February, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty three.
div3.closer:
Jefferson Davis.
By the Presidents.
Secretary of State.

Your friends of home expect this of you, and your down-trodden State turns to you for protection and make this demand upon you. Come one come all, in the headquarters of the Maryland Line corner of 8th had send streets, and at once in the service of your country.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p:
--In accordance with Special.
Order No. 39, from the Adjutant and inspector General's Office I am now in Fourteen on recruiting service, and announce the partial suspection of the Conscript law, so as to partial conscripts to volunteer he the companies of their own selection without passing through camps of instruction and to receive the county and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.

It is warless for me to make an appeal to your partition.
The desolate condition of the future portion of your State specks in stronger terms that anything could save.
Come forward, then, one end all, and volunteer at once, that the vile invader may be swept from the sacred not of your native State.
Any one within the conscript age who will come forward and volunteer will have the privatings of attaching himself to any company he may select, and will be furnished with transportation to the company on application to me. The will also receive $50 bounty and all other benefits provided by law cazes

All persons of conscript age, who have been authorised to appears before this board for final examination, will report immediately.

Ran away From the C, S 1st Becan's Quarter Branch about the 1st of February, two negro men named Delaware and Min.

Delaware was hired from F M Tabb & Son and belongs to Mrs. Jno Mutter of Hanover county, and was hired last year to Mr. George Turner.
He is a sort of bricklayer, and is probably doing job work about the city.
He is about 5 feet or 8 inches high, copper colored, and about 23 year of age.

Ben was hired from W S Philips, and belongs to Fing Graves of Chesterfield county.
He is back, about 5 feet 2 or 10 inches high and about 24 years old. I understand he is kind of backwater around the markets and the city, which occupation he may now be engaged to.
A liberal reward will be paid for the delivery of the above named negroes to me, or confined many jail in the city, so that they can be procured.
